content: Space Maze is an entirely new contribution and has absolutely nothing in common with Space Jam, which got refused by CodinBot.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
+1 eulerscheZahl

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Looks like a backtracking/wide search and simulation to me. Why very hard?
But looks fun

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Looks fun, and "very hard" is no joke at first sight indeed (but maybe I'll revise this after I manage to give it some more time).

My initial impression is that any solver would just solve it during the first turn and then just ignore further input and proceed to send pre-computed output. Makes having the whole per-turn input a bit pointless. But I'm not familiar with CG's custom puzzles restrictions, would removing per-turn input make it impossible to be animated?

It seems entirely possible to integrate the first turn input inside the initial input's ascii grid - i.e. U D L R for one-way platforms, H, V for horizontal/vertical, A or O for omni-direction platform, C/T or c/C for car/target (or a/A, b/B, c/C for the three-car version), etc. This does not assign ids to the platforms but the output commands could use coordinates instead of ids. Just mentioning it as an alternative to consider, though I don't mind leaving it as it is too. I guess it would be a somewhat large refactoring.

As you unfortunately can't see the validators: here they are https://www.codingame.com/ide/demo/826075dae5be09a761d9aa126a44281253ea00
The last testcase ("3 cars") is just an idea for a possible 2nd part of the puzzle - it's neither used as a testcase nor as a validator in this contribution.
Nice work. Have you solved it completely yet? :)

This is based on a game I played about 20 years ago. I can't remember the title, does anyone know the game?

And yes, I stole the sprites from A*Craft.
This is the one you were talking about the other evening, nice!

I have a solver. In fact I used that solver to generate most of the maps and verify that there is a solution but not a trivial one.

But my solver is too slow for testcase 14 and 16, which is why the contribution is still WIP.
Either I find a better way of solving it, or I simplify the testcases.

The game engine even supports a part 2 of the puzzle: you are given 3 cars and 3 target points. You can only move a platform with a car on it. Cars can collide and crash, making you lose. I just lack testcases (and a solver) for this.
Link is broken. :/

It is possible to only have a single input turn (see A*Craft or Bender4) and multiple frames.
I decided against it, as it follows the overall puzzle design on CodinGame (Vox Codei, There is no Spoon 2, ...).
My solver indeed only uses the first turn and then sends a list of actions.

The internal representation of my levels uses ASCII for every type (platform, car, ...). I only assign IDs on loading the testcases.
Again the main reason why I implemented it this way is to align with other games on the platform: ASCII map for static items, IDs for moving entities.
Mean bot :rage:

The search space is huge, you have to make some shortcuts to solve it in time.
I'm open to a discussion on the difficulty, after you solved it ;)
Here we go again
Damn, now i have to do it :D I make it "easy" and use your simulation, remember it should work on all languages ;)
Exactly. But in the original the car wasn't driving backwards, I'll fix that later :P
Is it rush hour, maybe ?

Unfortunately no, I came across that game as well while searching for mine.
The game I'm looking for has exactly one car and some movable platforms, as shown in this contribution.

It looks quite a lot like Stone Age, a ST/Amiga game with an awesome soundtrack.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gE5ZNP3D57M

Oh, interesting.
It's not the game from my memories but maybe mine is based on that.
Mine is a little less ancient I would say.
I think the general concept might probably pre-date even Stone Age.
